Latitude and Longitude - The system of imaginary lines used to identify any location on Earth with geographical coordinates.
Physical Geography - The study of natural features and processes on the Earth's surface, such as landforms, climate, and ecosystems.
Human Geography - The branch of geography that studies patterns and processes related to humans, including population, culture, urban development, and economic activity.
Cartography - The science of map-making. It encompasses both the aesthetics and science involved in creating a map.
Climate Zones - The division of the Earth's climates into specific climatic zones that are identified by specific criteria.
Ecosystems/Biomes - The various large-scale communities of flora and fauna that exist within geographic zones.
Continental Drift - The movement of the Earth's continents across the planet over geological time.
Globalization - The process by which businesses or other organizations develop international influence or start operating on an international scale.
Urbanization - The process of making an area more urban, usually involving the migration of people from rural areas to cities.
Population Density - Measurement of population per unit area or unit volume.
Cultural Diffusion - The spread of cultural beliefs and social activities from one group to another.
Geopolitics - The study of the effects of geography on politics and international relations.
Natural Resources - Resources that exist in a region naturally, such as minerals, forests, and water bodies.
Sustainability - The practice of using natural resources responsibly so they can support both present and future generations.
Geographic Information System (GIS) - A system used to capture, store, analyze, manage, and present spatial or geographic data.
